summary: Email correspondence between US and UK officials regarding a Mutual Legal Assistance (MLA) request to interview a material witness (referred to as "Material Witness PA") in investigations related to Jeffrey Epstein and Peter Nygard. The discussion centers on UK Home Office concerns about exhausting voluntary cooperation avenues before proceeding with the MLA, potential judicial review by the witness's lawyers (Blackfords), and the breakdown of trust between the US case team and the witness's counsel.

US and UK officials coordinating on legal assistance matters regarding the Epstein and Nygard investigations.
Senior UK and US officials corresponding about the MLA request process and timelines.

events.title: MLA Request Discussions
events.description: Ongoing discussions between US and UK authorities about executing a Mutual Legal Assistance request to interview a material witness in Epstein and Nygard investigations.

events.title: Blackfords Ceases Cooperation
events.description: Blackfords law firm sends written correspondence stating "there is no purpose to be served in continuing to try to assist further," indicating breakdown in voluntary cooperation.

events.title: Voluntary Cooperation Offer
events.description: The Prince's team (via Blackfords) offers voluntary cooperation to the Home Office, which becomes a point of contention in the MLA approval process.

locations: Home Office, 2nd Floor, Peel Building, 2 Marsham Street, London SW1P 4DF
keyFacts: The UK Home Office is hesitant to approve an MLA request to interview a material witness because the witness's lawyers (Blackfords) have offered voluntary cooperation, and the Home Office fears a judicial review if they don't exhaust voluntary avenues first.
US officials argue that requiring exhaustion of voluntary cooperation conflicts with the US-UK MLA treaty and would affect many cross-border cases.
There is a "significant mutual lack of trust" between the US case team and Blackfords law firm, making a voluntary interview outside the MLA context unlikely.
The material witness is of interest in both the Jeffrey Epstein and Peter Nygard investigations, though the facts on Nygard are described as "pretty thin."
The witness's counsel has stated their client is willing to assist but has not committed to specific steps, leading US officials to question whether this is posturing.
